parts.instructions: You are going to read an extract from a business magazine about workplace changes. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: The Changing Workplace
passage.content:
When Patricia Lopez arrived at the Metropolitan Business Center that morning, she noticed something different. The usual buzz of conversation from the open-plan office was replaced by an unusual quiet. Most employees were working from their individual pods, wearing headphones and focusing intently on their computer screens.

Patricia had been working as a business consultant for fifteen years, but the recent changes in workplace culture still surprised her. 'Five years ago, everyone gathered around the coffee machine to discuss projects,' she reflected. 'Now, most communication happens through digital platforms, even between colleagues sitting just meters apart.'

The transformation hadn't been sudden. It began gradually, with more companies adopting flexible working arrangements and digital collaboration tools. The pandemic accelerated these trends, but even as offices reopened, many of the changes remained permanent.

'What we're seeing is a fundamental shift in how people approach work,' explains Dr. Miguel Rodriguez, a workplace psychology researcher. 'Employees now prioritize efficiency and personal space over traditional team interactions. This isn't necessarily better or worse - it's simply different.'

Patricia observed that younger employees seemed to adapt more easily to these changes. They were comfortable with video calls, instant messaging, and collaborative software. However, some senior staff members struggled with the transition, preferring face-to-face meetings and traditional project management methods.

The challenge for managers, Patricia realized, was finding the right balance. 'We need to respect individual working preferences while maintaining team cohesion,' she noted. 'Some projects require intensive collaboration, while others are better suited to independent work.'

Companies that successfully navigated these changes shared certain characteristics. They invested in training programs, updated their technology infrastructure, and most importantly, listened to employee feedback. 'Change management isn't about imposing new systems,' Patricia concluded. 'It's about understanding what works for your specific team and adapting accordingly.'

options: A) Employees were having more conversations than usual.
B) The office atmosphere was quieter than normal.
C) Most people had arrived late for work.

options: A) All employees adapt equally well.

questions.text: What challenge do managers face according to Patricia?
options: A) Implementing new technology systems.
B) Balancing individual preferences with team needs.
C) Reducing office space requirements.
D) Training all employees in digital tools.

questions.text: What characterizes successful companies during workplace transitions?
options: A) They impose strict new policies.
B) They ignore employee complaints.

D) They avoid investing in new technology.

parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about career transitions. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: Making Career Changes
passage.content:
Changing careers can be one of life's most challenging yet rewarding experiences. Many professionals find themselves reconsidering their career paths, especially in today's rapidly evolving job market.

[7]

The first step in any career transition is honest self-assessment. This involves evaluating your current skills, interests, and values to determine what kind of work would truly satisfy you.

[8]

Many career changers make the mistake of focusing only on what they want to leave behind, rather than what they want to move toward. This negative approach can lead to hasty decisions and poor career choices.

[9]

Research is crucial during career transitions. This means not only studying potential new industries but also networking with professionals who are already working in your target field.

[10]

Financial planning plays a vital role in successful career changes. Most transitions involve some period of reduced income, whether due to additional training, starting at entry level, or taking time to build a new client base.

[11]

The psychological aspects of career change shouldn't be underestimated. Many people experience anxiety, self-doubt, and fear during transitions, which is completely normal.

[12]

Ultimately, successful career transitions require patience, planning, and persistence. Those who approach the process thoughtfully and systematically are most likely to achieve their goals.

paragraphs.text: Instead, successful career changers focus on their vision for the future and work systematically toward achieving their new professional goals.
Building a financial safety net before making major changes can reduce stress and provide more flexibility in timing your transition.
This might involve conducting informational interviews, attending industry events, or even volunteering in your area of interest.
Having support from family, friends, or professional counselors can make the difference between success and failure in career transitions.
The decision to change careers often comes after years of feeling unfulfilled or recognizing that your current path no longer aligns with your personal goals.
Consider taking career assessment tests or working with a professional career counselor to gain clarity about your strengths and preferences.
Some people change careers multiple times throughout their working lives, viewing each transition as an opportunity for growth and learning.

parts.instructions: You are going to read interviews with four people who made significant career changes. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Ana Santos - Former Lawyer, Now Chef
people.text: I spent ten years in corporate law before realizing I was completely burned out. The long hours and constant pressure were affecting my health and relationships. I'd always loved cooking and entertaining friends, so I decided to pursue culinary arts. It meant taking a huge pay cut and starting over, but I've never been happier. The creativity and immediate satisfaction of cooking are completely different from legal work. I had to take out loans to attend culinary school, but it was worth every penny.

people.name: Roberto Kim - Former Teacher, Now Software Developer
people.text: Teaching was rewarding, but I felt limited by budget constraints and bureaucracy. I was always interested in technology, so I started learning programming in my spare time. The transition took two years of intensive study while still teaching full-time. My previous experience managing classrooms actually helped with project management skills. The salary increase was significant, and I love the problem-solving aspect of coding. I can still educate people, just in a different way now.

people.name: Carmen Rodriguez - Former Accountant, Now Photographer
people.text: Numbers were my life for fifteen years, but I felt creatively stifled. Photography had been a hobby since college, but I never thought I could make a living from it. The transition was gradual - I started taking weekend wedding jobs while keeping my accounting position. Eventually, my photography income matched my accounting salary, so I made the switch. The irregular income was challenging at first, but the artistic satisfaction makes up for the financial uncertainty.

people.name: Luis Martinez - Former Engineer, Now Counselor
people.text: Engineering provided financial stability, but I felt disconnected from meaningful human interaction. I'd always been the person friends came to for advice, so I decided to pursue psychology. It required going back to university for four years while working part-time. The emotional demands of counseling are intense, but helping people work through their problems is incredibly fulfilling. My analytical background actually helps me approach therapy systematically.
